newsitem.title: FRANCE: FOCUS - French fourth-quarter GDP edges up 0.2 percent.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - French fourth-quarter GDP edges up 0.2 percent.

text.p: France's gross domestic product rose 0.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 1996 from the previous quarter, putting the country's depressed economy on a sounder base for its expected recovery this year.

The rise was slightly higher than economists' expectations but they said it was partly offset by a small downward revision to third quarter GDP growth, which rose 0.8 percent instead of an initially reported 0.9 percent.
A finance ministry official said the rise was in line with government expectations and made it more likely the country would reach its official 1997 growth target of 2.3 percent.
INSEE said full-year growth was 1.3 percent, in line with the government's official forecast, after growth of 2.2 percent in 1995.
"It's a nice surprise," said Herve Goulletquer, economist with Banques Populaires. "All the conditions are present for stronger growth in 1997."
The government needs stronger growth this year to fulfil its plans to reduce the public deficit in preparation for European monetary union.

The finance ministry official said growth would have been much stronger at the end of last year if the effect of the number of working days and a sharp drop in car sales were stripped out. Car sales were hit by the end of a government purchase-incentive scheme which expired at the end of September.
Economists said they expected growth in 1997 to be driven in large part by exports and stock-building, a shift from 1996, which drew much of its strength from consumer spending.
Consumer spending rose an annual average of 2.3 percent in 1996 and contributed 1.4 percentage points to full-year growth.
But economists said the positive GDP figure and stronger economic data so far this year should not lead to euphoria.
"I would stay on the cautious side," said Steven Englander, economist with Smith Barney in Paris, who said more data was needed to prove an economic recovery was here to stay.

Consumer sentiment remains mired at near all-time lows and unemployment is stuck at a record 12.7 percent. Englander said he still had some doubts about whether the economy would grow as much as the government expects.
Goulletquer, who had pencilled in 1997 growth of 2.2 percent before the report on Thursday, said an upward revision to 2.4 percent was possible, but no more.
INSEE said that in the fourth quarter, imports rose 1.3 percent but a 1.1 percent rise in exports cancelled most of that out and INSEE said trade's overall contribution to GDP was slightly negative.

Consumer spending, which dropped 0.5 percent, subtracted 0.3 percent from fourth-quarter growth, while investment was mildly positive for the quarter. Fourth-quarter growth was restrained, by less than a quarter of a percentage point, by the impact from the number of working days effect, INSEE added.
Stock-building contributed 0.4 percent growth to the fourth quarter while it subtracted 0.6 percent from full-year GDP growth.
